Report 1_Narrative: On takeoff roll Runway XX; Tower said another pilot reported flames coming out No1 engine or left side. Rejected takeoff; ran all checklists; and shut down engine. Never had any abnormal engine indications. Had them roll the fire trucks and upon inspection all appeared normal. No smoke or abnormals reported by flight attendants. After all checklists complete and contacting Company and Maintenance had fire trucks follow us to our gate. ELB entry followed up with verbal to Maintenance. First Officer and flight attendants did an excellent job!
Report 1_Synopsis: Captain reported a rejected take off due to a reported engine fire.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Instrument
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation - Altitude Excursion From Assigned Altitude; Deviation - Speed All Types; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Clearance; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; Flight Crew Diverted; General Maintenance Action
Report 1_Narrative: Due to weather and a supposed power outage at the airport; we were delayed approximately 1 hour from our scheduled departure time. This was the start of leg 2 for the day as we already operated out of ZZZ. There was another issue I will discuss after the conclusion of our [priority handling] event. [The] FO (First Officer) was pilot flying at the time. We took off out of ZZZ1 in very light rain throughout our departure. My FO stated it was barely enough rain to notice on the windshield. Light chop may have been experienced temporarily at most; but it was mostly smooth on climb out. We were cleared to flight level 31;000 where we stopped our descent. Shortly thereafter; while autopilot B was engaged; the autopilot started a significant descent all by itself. Unbeknownst to me and after speaking with my FO on the ground; the FO noticed his altimeter jumped from 31;000 ft. to 31;800 approximately. As soon as the autopilot started its descent; I took controls from the FO; disconnected the autopilot and leveled the airplane at 31;000 using my altimeter. I don't think we lost much altitude because I almost immediately disconnected the autopilot to arrest the pitch down moment. ATC shortly queried our altitude and we read back 31;000. ATC stated he saw us at approximately 31;700. About that time I looked over at the FO side and saw his altitude was the same as ATC verified 31700 ft. and looked at my display; which showed 31;000ft. ALT disagree was showing. At the same time; I noticed the FO airspeed was significantly slower than my airspeed and cross-checked the standby indicator - FO airspeed approximately 80 kt. slow. Airspeed disagree showed.At some point; I issued a pan pan pan. Standby airspeed and CA airspeed was the same and based on our thrust setting and altitude there was no doubt my FO's airspeed indicator was incorrect; 70-80 kt. too slow for our thrust and pitch setting. At that point; I determined; maybe incorrectly as I analyzed things on the ground; that since ATC had his altitude readout; I was basing our actual altitude on my FO's display and airspeed on my display. My reasoning is that 700-800 ft. high was safer than 700-800 ft. low; close to the ground; during approach and landing. Since I was now flying airspeed on my side and altitude on my FO's side; my altitude fluctuated up and down due to a gigantic 4 ft. scan instead of a normal 10 in. scan. Once I determined I could not hold altitude as expected; I asked for a block of altitude for airspace protection and was granted that clearance. The QRH for airspeed disagree was started; which led us to unreliable airspeed. We completed the checklist for unreliable airspeed and turned back towards ZZZ1. At some point after this realization I changed our pan pan to [requesting priority handling]. ATC apparently missed our [priority handling request] as he [provided priority handling] for us several minutes after I made the call myself. Upon realizing our altitude and airspeed unreliable; and ATC confirming ZZZ2 was VFR; I decided to turn back around another time to divert to ZZZ2 as it was a safer airport. Eventually; several altitude step downs were given to us for our descent into ZZZ2. QRH was completed and calls to Dispatch were then attempted.FO tried numerous times to contact company to relay our status and was unsuccessful. We attempted several calls on ZZZ3 Radio with no response. We asked ATC to call company and to contact us via ZZZ3 Radio; with no response from Dispatch. We then called on Guard to ask them to contact our Dispatch and let them know to contact us on ZZZ3 Radio; communication with Dispatch was never successful. With everything going on; I did not feel comfortable having my FO heads down sending an ACARS message...we were too busy.Descent checklist was soon completed and approach checklist was completed below 18;000. Holds were also accomplished to allow us time for checklists and getting weather info and setting up for the approach into ZZZ2 which were indicating 1100 ft. ceilings and better than required visibility. At some point in the descent; below 10;000 ft.; my FO realized the EEC were both in alternate mode and a discussion commenced. We discussed the thrust lever position and thrust changes that occurred in ALT mode but due to our [priority handling situation] and attempting to get the airplane on the ground safely; I forgot to have the FO run the QRH for the EEC alternate mode. Due to having no weather forecast and knowing weather was in the vicinity of ZZZ2 due to the hurricane remnants; my main concern was getting the aircraft on the ground safely in as close to VFR conditions as I could get.After landing; while discussing the events with my FO; we realized we probably should have made time to run this QRH procedure. I just didn't have the weather info in flight to make a call to continue holding to accomplish this checklist instead of landing. Landing VFR in my mind was a safer option than running this checklist and possibly losing VFR conditions due to hurricane remnants. The approach was set up and briefed and we commenced our approach. Checklists completed. CFR (Crash Fire Rescue) standing by for us. The approach and landing was uneventful.After landing we were given instructions to taxi down a taxiway; XX or XY; [which] I did not feel was safe for us to turn down [to] as it was too narrow for my comfort. I also had concern that the taxiway could support our weight and relayed to Ground Control that I would not be accepting that taxiway. We did a 180 on a closed runway as Ground gave us permission to do so and frankly; that was our only option due to where the aircraft was stopped on the taxiway.We then returned to [the FBO] and parked. [The] incident was written in [the] logbook with my initial impression on what happed; the caution messages we received and that I thought airspeed was good on my side only and altitude was good on the FO side only. Airplane was chocked and secured; no door seals were on the aircraft. We shut down; secured the airplane; and then did the supplementary procedure for powering the aircraft down. We then exited the aircraft and closed the door. We called for the FBO to remove the stairs from the airplane for security purposes. The stairs were then pulled back from the aircraft and we exited the Ramp into the FBO. [The] Chief Pilot; DOO; Dispatch and Maintenance Control [were] all notified via my personal phone. The earlier situation I referenced was a runway change at clearance for pushback. Since we had not started the engines or changed configuration; I had the FO change our assigned runway and then consulted the TLR (Thrust Lever Resolver) for new numbers. I showed the FO the TLR data and he verified correct data for runway change. I then read him the new data to input since we were pushing back. What I did not realize is that RTO1 had not been selected at that time; but all other number were entered. At some point during the takeoff; prior to 60 kt.; thrust was set; I noticed we had TO (Takeoff) selected instead of RTO1 based on the N1 setting. When I referenced our airspeed at this realization; we had already exceeded 80 kt. I think I made the 80 kt. call at 82 kt. I determined the safest outcome was to continue the takeoff based on our rejected takeoff parameters. I had in the back of my mind a 5 kt. difference in V1 between RTO1 and TO as I had looked earlier due to the weather in ZZZ1 at the time. This situation has led me to realize it is most likely a better habit to have the FO read off the TLR data and I enter the numbers myself in the FMC. This was something I just didn't catch as I was starting to get tired from sitting there for an extended time.[The cause was] airspeed and altitude [being] unreliable due to an unknown problem. After reflecting on what occurred; I believe none of the altitude or airspeed information on my FO's outboard display unit was correct. I erroneously believed that ATC's readout of our altitude confirmed my FO's altimeter was correct without realizing his entire system had likely failed; providing erroneous information to ATC. The weather from the hurricane was certainly a contributing factor as my main concern was getting the airplane on the ground safely and landing in VFR conditions.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737-800 flight crew reported an uneventful diversion due to unreliable airspeed and altitude indications during cruise.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Instrument
Events_Anomaly: Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy; Ground Event / Encounter Ground Strike - Aircraft
Events_Result: Aircraft Aircraft Damaged; General Maintenance Action
Report 1_Narrative: On touchdown at ZZZ; spoilers came out and caused the nose to rise. As a result; we had a tail strike. Reported this to MX (Maintenance) Control. Green band on tail strike cartridge was still showing but paint was scraped off. FAs (Flight Attendants) in rear of aircraft also heard the strike. Also spoke with [Company Safety] and [Flight Operations].I realize this is mentioned in the FH (Flight Handbook). I will add this to the brief for now on. I have personally only experienced it once. We may also want to add this to the initial or recurrent sim training.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737-900 Captain reported tail strike during landing.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP)
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy
Events_Detector: Automation Aircraft Other Automation; Person Flight Crew
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Air Traffic Control Issued New Clearance; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification; General Maintenance Action; General Flight Cancelled / Delayed
Report 1_Narrative: Leaving ZZZ an engine HYD SYS (Hydraulic System) A loss light illuminated. A SYS HYD Quantity at that time was normal. After approximately 2 hours into the flight A SYS HYD quantity fell to 16%. Although the A SYS HYD electric pump was providing pressure for the A SYS; I believed that there was potential that we might experience a total loss of the A SYS hydraulics once the landing gear was extended. I [requested priority handling] and contacted Dispatch. We extended the landing gear early and it extended normally. On approach; the gear and all other systems functioned normally. Landing was normal and uneventful. We taxied to the gate and discovered that we had a major HYD leak in the A SYS pump.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737 Captain reported loss of Hydraulic System A during cruise.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Multiengine
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy
Events_Result: Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; Flight Crew Diverted
Report 1_Narrative: At Flight Level 390 about 150 north of ZZZ we received a Warning Aft Cargo Fire; notified ATC that we had an emergency situation and wanted to head back to ZZZ. Worked the checklist for AFT Cargo Fire warning; extinguished the fire bottle; fire warning went out after a few minutes. Continued to ZZZ for normal approach and landing. Fire Crew detected no heat coming from cargo area; continued to the gate and was met by Maintenance. Last I heard no fire but failed sensing. Flight crew did excellent job.
Report 1_Synopsis: Air Carrier Flight Crew flying 777-200 aircraft reported aft cargo fire warning in flight.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Attendant Current
Events_Anomaly: Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy; Flight Deck / Cabin / Aircraft Event Illness / Injury; Flight Deck / Cabin / Aircraft Event Smoke / Fire / Fumes / Odor
Events_Result: General Physical Injury / Incapacitation
Report 1_Narrative: I started to feel nauseous during the flight from ZZZ1 to ZZZ. After we completed service; [Person A] and I started to smell a strong sour milk smell in the aft galley. It came and went about three times. We could not find a source for the smell; and no passengers complained of anything. The last time we noticed the smell was before descent. At this point my nausea had gotten worse. During final descent I started to feel a little lightheaded and dizzy. I thought it was getting better; but when I bent down to disarm my door; I had a hard time getting back up from being so lightheaded. At that point I asked [Person A] if she was feeling ok. She said she had been feeling lightheaded. So during deplaning I called the [Person B] and let her know what we were feeling. She told the Captain who suggested we talk to a supervisor and get checked out in case it was a cabin air quality event. We were met by a supervisor who then called EMTs to check us out. We decided to then go to the ER where we got blood tests; and it was determined that we had carbon monoxide poisoning. We listened to our bodies and paid attention when something was out of the norm.
Report 1_Synopsis: Flight Attendant reported a 'sour milk' smell was noticed during flight resulting in health issues. Post-flight diagnosis determined it was carbon monoxide poisoning.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP)
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical
Events_Result: Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification; Flight Crew Took Evasive Action; Flight Crew Became Reoriented
Report 1_Narrative: While cruising at 38;000 feet in VFR conditions the TCAS RA alert sounded. The First Officer and I performed the memory items and initiated the commanded climb. I advised ATC of our situation and was told by the controller that no other aircraft were observed in our area. TCAS then commanded us to descend and we also complied while looking outside for any intruding aircraft. The alert then said we were clear and went away. We regained our original altitude with no further conversation with ATC. All appeared normal and we determined the alert was false. The TCAS gave us 2 more false alarms. The 2nd was level at 30;000 feet and the 3rd was at 3;000 feet. While being vectored for the ILS Approach. Once on the ground the faulty TCAS was written up. Maintenance and Dispatch were made aware of the problem. After talking to Maintenance I was informed the TCAS system had been a continuing problem with multiple write-ups. I believe we were the first to get an RA alert; but it would've helped if someone had given us a heads up.
Report 1_Synopsis: A Flight Crew reported receiving false TCAS RA advisories and stated maintenance told them it was a recurring issue with their aircraft.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP)
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Issued New Clearance; Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Aircraft Equipment Problem Dissipated; Aircraft Aircraft Damaged; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; Flight Crew Diverted
Report 1_Narrative: Climbing out; approximately XX00Z; the left engine had loss of thrust associated with compressor stall / surges. Flight attendants rang the call button and indicated they heard loud banging and wanted to verify we heard the same. We shallowed our climb then leveled off at FL 280 and [advised ATC]. Subsequent flight attendant chime indicated they saw flames had extended aft of the #1 engine. We had already begun to tackle the surge / stall QRC followed by QRH checklist when they called advised of flames. We recognized and agreed that ZZZ was our best option due to proximity (80 miles roughly ) off our nose with optimum field capabilities. We coordinated with flight attendants and talked with a non-rev commuting Company Captain who had been sitting on left side of cabin and had seen the flames. During this process; we coordinated with ATC for direct and began a descent to ZZZ [and] fired off a quick message to Dispatch indicating engine malfunction and plan to divert. We coordinated with crew of the precautionary landing and advised passengers of our intentions. In the descent we completed the appropriate checklists; acquired the [weight and balance] data for landing in addition to brake cooling then were vectored for a visual approach to [Runway] XXL. We landed uneventfully and taxied clear of the runway and we were met by Fire and Rescue. We shut down the #1 engine and awaited CFR to evaluate. CFR gave us the all clear and we taxied to gate and began to coordinate with all appropriate personnel.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737 flight crew reported engine compressor stall and surges resulted in divert to precautionary landing.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP)
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy
Events_Result: Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition
Report 1_Narrative: On approach to ZZZ when flaps one was selected a 'FLT CTRL flap slat' disagree message was displayed on ECAM (Electronic Centralized Aircraft Monitor). Slats remained at zero as flaps were selected. ATC was notified of situation and need for vectors for time to perform checklists. ATC was advised. Checklists and ECAM items were completed as well as landing APP on iPad for a no slat flap 3 landing. ACARS (Aircraft Communications And Reporting System) message to Dispatch was sent informing them [our reporting] with ATC and our no slat situation. Flight attendants and passengers were briefed of situation and to expect a normal landing with the exception of the presence of some airport vehicles. A non-eventful landing on [Runway] XXC was made followed by a normal taxi to the gate. Failure of slats to deploy when selected.
Report 1_Synopsis: A321 flight crew reported slat failure on approach.

Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical
Events_Result: Flight Crew Executed Go Around / Missed Approach; Flight Crew FLC complied w / Automation / Advisory
Report 1_Narrative: On approach; upon selecting Flaps 2; 'FLT CONT flaps fault' on ECAM. We discontinued the approach and performed ECAM procedures and QRH follow up for 'slats; no flaps' landing. Vectors for another visual approach. Performed an uneventful 'no flaps' landing. Weather was clear with unrestricted visibility; therefore we arrived with about 6;800 lbs. fuel. Factoring in :45 min reserve; we had about 25-30 min max. remaining fuel to troubleshoot. More fuel would have made the flight more comfortable.
Report 1_Synopsis: A319 flight crew member reported a safe 'slats; no flaps' landing after executing a go-around in response to 'FLT CONT flaps fault' ECAM.

Events_Anomaly: Flight Deck / Cabin / Aircraft Event Smoke / Fire / Fumes / Odor

Report 1_Narrative: Just prior to level off at FL370 FO and I decided we should go back to FL 350 for wider margin. As we were about to descend from FL357 back to FL350 we heard a squealing noise which turned to a vibration followed by smell of acrid smoke. Donned O2 masks and advised ATC and new destination of ZZZ. FO was flying Pilot and remained so. I ran checklists and accomplished communications with Dispatch and company.[Captain theorized possible cause] a blower motor failed.
Report 1_Synopsis: A321 Captain reported noticing a 'smell of acrid smoke' during cruise resulting in a diversion.

Report 1_Narrative: Captain's window opened and detached from aircraft during climbout. All checklists were completed; perhaps they were not completed in normal sequence due to severe noise associated with window detachment. Aircraft configuration was fulfilled after much consternation due to nearly nil communication due to wind noise and headset loss.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737 Captain reported that the Captain's side window opened and became detached during climbout.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP)
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical
Events_Result: Flight Crew Inflight Shutdown; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition
Report 1_Narrative: Near top of climb we had an intermittent ENG 1 OIL LO PR Amber Caution message which became a steady RED Warning message. I performed the ECAM (Electronic Centralized Aircraft Monitor) actions and follow up for the message which included shutting down the engine. The Captain [advised ATC]. We landed without further incident.I don't know what caused the indication but we had multiple indications which led us to believe it was not an erroneous indication and resulted ultimately in the engine shutdown per the ECAM.I believe it was a mechanical issue but I was unable to find a clear procedure for what to do for an intermittent (or even steady) ENG 1 OIL LO PR Amber Caution message with other supporting indications. Having a discussion in training about unusual/non standard situations would be helpful insight. ATC was very accommodating and we found it helpful to have ATC provide us a separate frequency to communicate with Tower and ARFF (Aircraft Rescue Fire Fighting) simultaneously. ARFF was very responsive and communication was excellent. It was a seamless process on final approach with our requests.
Report 1_Synopsis: Air Carrier Flight Crew flying A-321 aircraft reported low engine oil pressure inflight.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Instrument
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical
Events_Result: Flight Crew Inflight Shutdown; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition
Report 1_Narrative: The crew departed ZZZ on time after calling maintenance to reset a Rudder Trim Limiter ECAM malfunction. Pushback; start; taxi; takeoff and climb out were uneventful. Passing FL260 for a cruise altitude of FL270 the First Officer (Pilot Monitoring) identified a flashing oil quantity advisory reading and a low oil pressure indication on the #1 engine system display. Due to the aircraft's momentum and vertical rate of climb the Captain (Pilot Flying) elected to level off at FL270 as planned. Initially the zero oil quantity and low 60 PSI pressure indication were not accompanied by an ECAM message and system status indicated normal. Within a couple of minutes a series of intermittent ECAM cautions and warnings occurred leading to an engine shutdown condition. The amber ENG 1 OIL LO PR Caution illuminated first on the ECAM display. The crew responded by initiating the company non-normal checklist strategy. The Captain announced 'my aircraft' then the First Officer verified that the ECAM was not a Quick Action or ECAM exception item. The Captain elected to remain flying and also took control of the radio. It was a crew awareness only caution so the FO (First Officer) then checked the QRH for follow up items. This Caution does not direct the crew to adjust thrust settings. During this process the caution [message] cleared itself without any inputs from the crew but the zero oil quantity and 60 PSI indications remained. At this point the ECAM display was clear and system status indicated normal. Shortly thereafter the red ENG 1 LO PR warning illuminated on the ECAM display. This occurred intermittently 3 times and then cleared itself each time resulting in a normal system status display on the ECAM. Oil quantity remained at zero and pressure was now steady at 40 PSI on the system display. These intermittent ECAM warnings lasted for approximately 2-3 seconds and then cleared to a normal status for roughly the same amount of time. The next time the ECAM warning illuminated it remained steady and the crew followed the ENG 1 LO PR warning procedures and shutdown the engine. The crew notified Center and requested a radar vector descent to final for the engine out approach at ZZZ1. The non-normal indications initially occurred just prior to the ETP (equal time point) between ZZZ and ZZZ1. However by the time the ECAM directed engine shutdown the flight had progressed passed the ETP and was at a normal descent point for ZZZ1. Dispatch was called using the iPad crew phone and notified of the nature of the emergency and decision to land at ZZZ1. The flight attendants and passengers were briefed about the Precautionary Landing at ZZZ1 and the possibility of airport fire vehicles near the aircraft. After shutting down the engine and notifying ATC; the crew requested and was given a vector and descent direct to a left 10 NM base at ZZZ1. Descent and approach were very stable and normal. The Captain flew the descent and approach with both the autopilot and auto thrust on. Crew requested ARFF (airport rescue fire department) for the landing and cleared the runway for a brief inspection of the engine. On request of the crew the fire department followed the aircraft to the gate. Shutdown at the gate and passenger deplaning were normal. Note: ATC handling by ZZZ Center; ZZZ1 Approach and Tower were outstanding. Handoff from Tower to ARFF at ZZZ1 was seamless and well coordinated. Flight Attendant performance was also outstanding and the passengers remained well informed throughout the emergency. Although oil fault indications were somewhat intermittent and erratic the fact that multiple independent sensors indicated a problem caused the crew to shutdown the #1 engine when directed by the ENG LO PR Warning ECAM. After the flight; maintenance personnel initially reported normal engine oil quantity on a sight gauge even though the engine instrument remained at zero. Initially crew suspects a partial blockage or pump failure in the system without oil loss. The engine oil quantity and pressure indications were initially both alarming and confusing. As the adrenaline level increased for the crew due to the perception there would be an engine shutdown there was also a level of doubt that the indications were accurate. Low oil pressure on the engine instrument should be accompanied by a Low Pressure ECAM Caution or Warning. Why did the pressure remain steady in the amber range with zero on the quantity? This is an uncomfortable situation because our training does not address multiple oil failures without ECAM warnings. It puts the flight crew into one of those gray areas where a Captain is expected to make a decision based on the information he has on hand in a situation not covered in training. The natural instinct of a pilot is to shutdown an engine before complete oil loss to prevent a catastrophic failure. In this occurrence engine indications identified a problem well in advance of ECAM warnings. Yet crew training and aircraft procedures generally do not address engine shutdown without ECAM warning checklist direction. Should crews be given shutdown discretion in the absence of ECAM warnings and checklist? In this situation the Captain elected to continue as the Pilot Flying while the crew worked through the non-normal checklist strategy. Even though most aspects of company's non-normal strategy were performed correctly the overall pace and structure were hampered by the Captain continuing to fly. In this case the checklist strategy would have been better managed if the Captain had delegated flying to the FO. For example; when the ECAM directed the 'Engine Master Switch-Off' both pilots confirmed it was the #1 engine but the Captain positioned it to off. Procedure dictates that the non-flying pilot position the switch to off.
Report 1_Synopsis: Air Carrier Captain flying A321 aircraft reports low engine oil pressure inflight.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP)
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical
Events_Result: Flight Crew Diverted; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition
Report 1_Narrative: I was the Pilot Flying on this leg. After departing ZZZ1 while climbing through Flight Level 280 on our way up to FL340 Autopilot #1 disconnected and would not reengage. A/P (Autopilot) #2 would engage but after about 30 seconds it also disengaged along with the auto thrust going into THRUST LOCK mode. Then several ECAMs (Electronic Centralized Aircraft Monitor) appeared including RUD TRIM1 FAULT; YAW DAMPER 1; RUD TRV LIM 1. The First Officer ran the Quick Reference Handbook procedures for each of those problems which included resetting the FACs (Flight Augmentation Computer).We leveled at FL340 and the aircraft was exhibiting a slight Dutch Roll tendency so we descended to FL280 and no more Dutch Roll was observed. Autopilots could be intermittently engaged; flight directors would come and go; autothrust would disengage in THRUST LOCK mode. We consulted with Dispatch and [Maintenance Control] via phone patch. Without further attempting to engage autopilots or autothrust events seemed to stabilize and with consult with Dispatch we planned to continue to destination. We began evaluating along route alternates and asked Dispatch to do the same. Shortly thereafter the flight directors started to come and go repeatedly along with the previously described ECAMS. When each rudder ECAM came and went there was a discernible yaw felt. Other messages would appear momentarily then clear such as 2FD2; and BOTH PFDs (Primary Flight Display) on SINGLE SOURCE (not sure of the wording as it would momentarily flash then disappear).At this time we made the decision to divert and after evaluating the weather decided with dispatch concurrence to divert to ZZZ2. An [urgent situation] was declared with ATC and a clearance to ZZZ2 was obtained and a safe landing was made. ECAMS intermittently continued while enroute.The aircraft was always fully under control. After gate arrival I debriefed with the [Flight Manager] and maintenance log entries were submitted. Briefed local ZZZ2 maintenance personnel.
Report 1_Synopsis: Air Carrier Captain flying A319 aircraft diverted due to aircraft mechanical malfunction.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Instrument
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Flight Deck / Cabin / Aircraft Event Smoke / Fire / Fumes / Odor
Events_Detector: Person Flight Crew; Person Flight Attendant
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; Flight Crew Diverted; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification; General Maintenance Action
Report 1_Narrative: While climbing to our cruise altitude the Captain and I began to hear a noise coming from the cabin that sounded to us like a pressurization leak in the airplane. Shortly thereafter the Captain received a call from the cabin crew; I believe notifying him about the same noise we were hearing. We then asked ATC for a lower altitude in hopes of the noise stopping. Shortly after that the Captain received another call from the cabin crew; when he hung up the phone he told me we were returning to our departure airport ZZZ due to claims of smoke or fumes in the cabin. I then donned my oxygen mask and notified ATC with our intentions to return to ZZZ. We were then given a lower altitude and vectors. We conducted the smoke/fumes checklist. We also decided ZZZ1 airport would be closer and notified ATC we would be landing there. We landed in ZZZ1 without incident where we had the ARFF (airport rescue firefighters) search our aircraft for any hot spots while still on the runway. After no hot spots were found we taxied to the gate where we deplaned normally. The pressurization leak that caused a loud noise and I never heard what the cabin crew smelled in the cabin. I really can't come up with any suggestions that would have prevented this event without knowing what caused the leak and what caused the smell.
Report 1_Synopsis: A321 First Officer reported a cabin fumes event during climb and cruise level off resulting in a diversion. The fumes were reportedly caused by a pressurization leak.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP)
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Less Severe; Flight Deck / Cabin / Aircraft Event Smoke / Fire / Fumes / Odor
Events_Detector: Person Flight Crew; Person Flight Attendant
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; General Maintenance Action
Report 1_Narrative: Just after departing ZZZ; heard F/A's on cabin inter phone complaining of an odor in the cabin.  About that same time; the FO and myself noticed an electrical/plastic melting odor in the cockpit.  Performed Avionics Smoke procedure in the QRH.  Smell dissipated after selecting Blower and Exhaust fans to override and turning off cabin fans and galley equip. Confirmed odor was dissipating with the cabin crew; so after some discussion; we decided to continue to ZZZ1.  Talked with dispatch and Maintenance Control; filed out fume event report.  We [advised ATC] to minimize delay getting into ZZZ1 and as we begun defending thru 10;000 ft; the fumes returned.  FO and myself both donned out oxygen masks and got the a/c on the ground in ZZZ1 as quickly as possible.No casual factors involved. About a serious event as can be!Unsure where the actual source of fumes came from.
Report 1_Synopsis: A320 flight crew reported an uneventful landing at destination after experiencing a fumes event noticed throughout the aircraft.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Instrument
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Clearance; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Flight Crew Diverted; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; General Maintenance Action
Report 1_Narrative: I was CA (Captain) and PM (Pilot Monitoring).  Departed late due to ELAC (Elevator & Aileron Computer) 1 MEL (Minimum Equipment List).  South of ZZZ at FL390; we had ECAM for HYD (Hydraulic) G RSVR (Reservoir) LO AIR PR (Low Air Pressure).  I ran the ECAM and told ATC we had a HYD issue.  ECAM put us into ATL LAW (Alternate Law) and FO (First Officer) had to hand fly.  We asked for lower altitude and told ATC we wanted ZZZ1 and I sent ACARS to Dispatch.   I was running the COM and getting ATIS and found out ZZZ was showing 002OVC (200' Overcast) and 1 1/2 vis (Visibility).  I asked ATC if there was anything better for weather and he said the region was all the same.  We decided to go to ZZZ.  Once the COM was complete I called and briefed the FA's (Flight Attendants) and made PA to the passengers.  We decided that I would take over and fly the approach and landing. We briefed the ILS 11 Approach and the FO hand flew the Aircraft until about 15-20 mile final so I could take my time and take a few minutes to 'gather my thoughts.'  We started to configure early and we had to gravity extend the gear.  Now we were in direct law and started to fly the approach..  We saw the approach lights and continued and saw the runway at minimums.  We landed.  We taxied to the gate and briefed the passengers and deplaned.  I made the phone calls to Company; Dispatch and Maintenance.  Maintenance looked at the issue and found out there was HYD fluid all over and we had a bad O ring. They fixed the issue and we were about to land in ZZZ1 about 5 hours late.
Report 1_Synopsis: A320 Captain reported a Hydraulic System Failure inflight resulting in a diversion.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP)
Events_Anomaly: ATC Issue All Types; Ground Event / Encounter Person / Animal / Bird; Ground Event / Encounter Fuel Issue
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Air Traffic Control Issued New Clearance; Flight Crew Executed Go Around / Missed Approach; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification
Report 1_Narrative: Great weather; normal fuel burn. Entering terminal area we were vectored around then low and slow which created more fuel burn in terminal area. Did go-around for XXL due to an animal on runway. Aircraft in front of us did same. Declared minimum fuel on go-around in order to expedite landing since fuel now was an issue with extra fuel burn and not much to play. Controller was going to extend us downwind behind an arriving aircraft which would have added more time and fuel so I elected to [request] an immediate turn to the FAF for XXC. I didn't want XXL because of animal issue and another possible go-around. Controller vectored preceding aircraft off their approach and cleared us for visual XXC. Landed uneventfully with 3.9 fuel.....2.10 left tank and 1.8 right tank. Reserve Fuel on Flight Plan was 3.78.Cause: Dispatched with normal arrival fuel with very good weather. Controller vectored us low and slow which increased fuel burn. Suggestions: Next time I will not accept so many vectors and low and slow increasing fuel burn when I do not have extra fuel to play.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737-800 Captain reported a low fuel situation developed following a go-around to avoid an animal on the runway.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP)
Person 1_Human Factors: Communication Breakdown; Human-Machine Interface; Troubleshooting; Workload
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; General Flight Cancelled / Delayed
Report 1_Narrative: After Takeoff on our climb up 2;500 ft. out of ZZZ; we lost the use of both VHF radios com1 and com2. We leveled off at 2;500 ft. worked the problem and the Captain was able to get com1 back by using the ALT switch. All the communications on the First Officer side of the plane had died I could not use the hot mic or communicate with ATC on my side I tired different headsets and nothing worked. We then decided to return to ZZZ since we were going out over the water on our way to ZZZ1. WE had to burn 14;000 lbs. of fuel to get under max landing weight. We ended up holding over ZZZ VOR since the weather in the area was raining and turbulent and ZZZ VOR was in the clear and smooth. We worked the Flight Attendant; Dispatch; Maintenance Control; and ATC; till we had burned off enough fuel to return to land in ZZZ. We kept the passengers informed of what was going on as much as we could during the entire event.
Report 1_Synopsis: Air carrier First Officer reported that both VHF radios stopped working during departure; resulting in a diversion.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Multiengine
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical
Events_Result: Flight Crew Diverted; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; General Flight Cancelled / Delayed; General Maintenance Action
Report 1_Narrative: We were at cruise when we noted the right engine oil pressure at 6 (normally around 12). We see that the number was going down; showing that we are losing oil. I started to go through the iPad QRH for an appropriate checklist. While looking; the Captain said 'your aircraft' so I took over pilot duties (it was his leg). He was looking at the Low Oil checklist when the oil qty went to zero; and the Captain decided to just shutdown the engine before it got worse. We [advised ATC] and a turn back towards ZZZ. We ran the engine shutdown checklist. I was flying; he was doing the checklists; radio; and the procedures; as recommended by our training department. We were still over max landing weight; and needed time to run all the supplemental checklists and procedures; so we decided to land at ZZZ and burn fuel to get under max landing weight at the same time. The single engine ILS into ZZZ was textbook. We taxied off the runway; was inspected by CFR; and then taxied to the gate.The Low Oil Quantity checklist is not easily found; as it is not in the index as 'low oil quantity' or 'oil low quantity' and it only reference oil pressure in the index.There was no audio or visual alert; when the oil quantity was half what it was supposed to be. We just happened to catch the small indication on the lower screen; and watched it drop to zero. I don't think we could have caught it any faster than we did.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737-800 flight crew reported loss of engine oil; causing an in-flight shut down and a diversion to a precautionary landing.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Instrument
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; Flight Crew Diverted; Flight Crew Landed As Precaution
Report 1_Narrative: On climbout lost flight instruments ADI HSI both sides and navigation capability.  Was on standby instruments.  I took the aircraft from FO and requested priority handling. With help from ATC.  Landed VFR safely at ZZZ.  Found the IRUs not properly aligned.With constant interruptions preparing for the flight by flight attendants; fuel slips; security forms; I failed to properly align the IRUs.  I usual devote my attention to this process and can only imagine that I got interrupted.  I was also tired.  Everything seemed normal on taxi out.  I was able to update the position at the end of the runway.  I had a First Officer brand new to the airplane.  Just finished IOE.  Ultimately it was my fault I take full responsibility.  I feel terrible about it.  Pilot error on my part.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737-300 Captain reported they lost flight instruments on both sides and navigation capability during climbout resulting in a diversion.  Captain stated the IRUs were not properly aligned and cited multiple distractions and fatigue as contributing factors.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Instrument
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Ground Event / Encounter Loss Of Aircraft Control
Events_Result: Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; Flight Crew Returned To Departure Airport; General Flight Cancelled / Delayed; General Maintenance Action
Report 1_Narrative: After takeoff landing gear would not retract. ECAM L/G (Landing Gear) SHOCK ABSORBER fault observed. Shortly A/P (Auto Pilot) and Auto Thrust disconnected. Flight Directors; A/P; Auto Thrust were intermittent throughout entire flight. Captain ran appropriate checklist while PF (Pilot Flying) manually flew aircraft. Notified ATC; notified Dispatch; flight attendants and passengers of intent to return to ZZZ. Lost navigation auto-tuning radios on approach executed go-around. Hard tuned radios manually and flew raw data approach. Approach and initial touchdown were normal. Once nose wheel made contact with the ground; aircraft began to shake and stopped on the runway. ECAM LGCIU 2 fault appeared told passengers and flight attendants to remain seated and requested ARFF (Aircraft Rescue and Firefighting) to come to aircraft. No fire observed by ARFF.  Maintenance confirmed nose gear was 90 degrees to the aircraft centerline.   Maintenance replaced nose tires and passengers were deplaned onto buses and returned to the terminal. Aircraft was towed to Maintenance. Communication with Company; flight attendants and airport was good.
Report 1_Synopsis: A319 flight crew reported a nose gear malfunction after takeoff resulting in a return to departure airport.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Attendant Current; Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP)

Report 1_Narrative: On climb out after 5 min. for approximately 15 min. FA (Flight Attendants) 3 and 4 reported smelling sweet glue like odor that went away in about 15 min. About 35 min. into flight FA 3 reported a headache and FA 4 reported headache and nausea. FA 2 reported the smell was faint but did smell it but felt OK. FA 1 and flight deck did not smell odor. The odor was noted from Row 10 to aft of aircraft. The FA 4 reported feeling worse at 35 min. into flight so we elected to return to ZZZ. 1 passenger in 13A reported slight irritation in nose and slight headache. On return to ZZZ as a [prioritized] aircraft on descent through 10;000 ft. flight deck and cabin noticed a distinct odor like Elmer's Glue. Uneventful landing with flight deck on O2 and cabin use of 4 portable O2 bottles. FA 4 went to hospital remaining crew felt fine and continued on new aircraft to ZZZ1 as rescheduled.The probable cause was possible oil leak but no indications in flight deck.Dependent on maintenance findings.
Report 1_Synopsis: A321 Captain reported a cabin fumes event during initial climb resulting in a return to the departure airport.

Report 1_Narrative: My first attempt at writing this portion did not save so I will attempt it again. We had an A321 sharklet. Every portion of the beginning of the flight leg from gate departure; takeoff and climb up to the fume event was normal and routine. At sometime above 10;000 ft. we got a call from our #1 FA (Flight Attendant) telling us that the FAs in Economy Class more towards the rear of the aircraft were smelling a sweat odor and a more robust glue type odor. I believe from my prospective that the odor came from the back from the wings black wards because we did not smell anything in the flight deck and no one smelled anything in first class; #1 FA or forward section of the cabin behind 1st class section. Captain began trouble shooting the problem with the QRH guidelines and the FAs that was smelling the odors. One of the FAs was feeling ill from the fume which was strong in the area they were working. Passenger in that area smelled the odors as well. Captain asked if she can continue or do we need to get back to the gate in ZZZ so she can seek medical attention. She was not sure if she wanted to continue on toward ZZZZ1 or return. Captain asked the #1 FA to monitor the FA's condition and if she worsened we will return to ZZZ. While we were discussing the QRH fume trouble shooting pages and making plans to return to ZZZ or another airport that may be closer to our position if we continued to fly farther away from ZZZ; the #1 FA called and told us the FA that was feeling ill was on O2 and was not getting better. So we notified ATC that we will be returning to ZZZ which was the best option to land. We [were given priority handling] to expedite our return to ZZZ and so the FA can get the medical attention she needed. As we began to descend into ZZZ I remember it was below FL180 and through landing that the odors began to infiltrate the flight deck and the #1 FA and passengers began smelling it too. We donned our O2 masks. It was a sweaty smell and it also had an Elmer's glue order to us. The odors continued until we arrived to the gate. The FA that was really ill went to the hospital and the remaining flight crew continued with us to ZZZZ1 with a replacement FA.I don't know of any causal factors that would cause a fume event other than fixing the problem of the source that caused the fumes from escaping and preventing and future leaks from going into the cabin.The only thing that would prevent this from happening would be a complete redesign of the airplane systems that keeps the cabin ventilation isolated from any possible fume leaking into the cabin.
Report 1_Synopsis: A321 First Officer reported a fumes event during departure climb resulting in a return to the departure airport.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP)
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Less Severe; Conflict Ground Conflict; Less Severe; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy; Ground Event / Encounter Weather / Turbulence; Ground Incursion Runway
Events_Result: Flight Crew Took Evasive Action
Report 1_Narrative: Landed on a runway with snow removal equipment on it. While on rollout; the low visibility obscured runway activity until no other choice was available.Onboard equipment failed; distracting crew from making radio positions reporting to ZZZ traffic. Event occurred after Tower had closed for the night.Good accident prevention was conducted by all vehicles and aircraft involved; and no other problems occurred.This could have been a classic example of 'Chain of events causing a accident.'  A late departure because of icing conditions at origin. Weather at arrival airport causing snow removal equipment to be on runway for extended periods of time. A minor problem during the approach to landing phase distracted the crew; and company procedures required crew to be playing the role of both flying and non-flying pilot at the same time.      In this case; I believe; safety would have been better served if once the decision to hand off control was made; we didn't change back 600-400 feet above the ground. Once the decision was made our roles would have been clearer; and airplane radio communication would have been made at the critical trigger points.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737 flight crew reported a ground conflict with an airport vehicle during landing roll at an airport that was non-towered at the time of the event. The crew did not make the proper CTAF radio announcements prior to landing.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Multiengine
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Clearance; Inflight Event / Encounter Fuel Issue
Events_Detector: Automation Aircraft Other Automation; Person Flight Crew
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Flight Crew Returned To Departure Airport; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification; General Maintenance Action; General Flight Cancelled / Delayed
Report 1_Narrative: Captain was pilot monitoring. FO (First Officer) was pilot flying. Passing through 4;000 feet MSL on climbout from ZZZ we noticed a fuel imbalance developing - right wing main tank fuel indication already 400 pounds lower than left wing. Right wing main tank fuel appeared to be feeding at approximately twice the rate of the left and it appeared that the center tank fuel was not feeding at all. Engine fuel flow readings appeared normal and equal. By 10;000 feet MSL the imbalance had increased to the point that the IMBAL alert was activated. We coordinated with ATC to level off at 12;000 feet MSL in order to reduce fuel flow and begin taking appropriate action. Upon leveling at 12;000 feet MSL we observed the right fuel tank quantity feed rate appear to normalize and then observed a 50 pound increase in right main tank fuel quantity. Fuel imbalance at that point was 1;100 pounds. We initiated the IMBAL checklist in the QRH. Observing what then appeared to be normal tank quantity indications for a crossfeed operation; we coordinated with ATC to continue our climb and proceed on course to the destination knowing we would also coordinate with Dispatch and maintenance promptly to determine if proceeding to ZZZ1 was advisable. As soon as we established climb fuel flow settings and pitch attitude; the right main tank quantity began to decrease again at what appeared to be the same abnormal rate observed during the initial climb. We then requested priority handling initiated the return to ZZZ (nearest airport) and started the APU as a precaution. I advised Dispatch; the cabin crew; and the passengers of the situation using SOP. As soon as we stopped the climb to initiate the return to ZZZ the right main fuel tank indication again stopped decreasing at an abnormal rate. We concluded the IMBAL checklist and for the remainder of the flight we observed no further indications of abnormal rate of decrease in right main wing tank fuel. During the descent; I spoke with the flight attendants and they confirmed that there were no visible indications of fuel leaks on either wing or engine. We landed uneventfully at ZZZ with a total imbalance of 1;220 pounds with 8;370 pounds in the left wing; 7;150 pounds in the right wing and 13;470 pounds in the center tank - 29;000 points total. The aircraft was below max landing weight at touchdown. ARFF (Airport Rescue and Firefighting) personnel were standing by as requested. After landing and before further taxi; ARFF personnel inspected the aircraft closely and reported no leaks; no visible damage; and no abnormalities. We shut down the number 2 engine as an additional precaution and requested that the ARFF vehicles follow us to our gate. Maintenance personnel were debriefed in person at the gate upon arrival.Captain suspects suspect faulty fuel crossfeed valve.Reporter recommends company consider revisiting the IMBAL checklist in light of this particular malfunction.
Report 1_Synopsis: B73-800 Captain reported an uneventful air return due to an airborne fuel system malfunction during initial climb.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Instrument
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical
Events_Result: Flight Crew Diverted; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition
Report 1_Narrative: All crews should be informed and knowledgeable about emergency procedures in order to be prepared for such unexpected events in flight.After an uneventful preflight preparation and exterior inspection we departed ZZZ; myself as Pilot Flying and the Captain as Pilot Monitoring. We climbed to planned cruise altitude without issue. Shortly after reaching cruise and just south of ZZZ1; an ECAM message and associated chime presented on the lower ECAM screen indicating 'ENG 1 SYSTEM FAULT'. We worked through the indicated actions and referenced the COM procedures. As the engine was reduced to idle thrust only; we began a descent and began diversion planning as it became clear that we could not continue to ZZZ2 with this issue at the lower altitude required on a single engine at ZZZ3. Initially ZZZ was selected; but while I was flying and communicating with ATC the Captain in consultation with the dispatcher elected to divert instead to ZZZ4. With plenty of time to prepare we did all necessary tasks for the diversion and proceeded to an uneventful landing on ZZZ's longest runway; XXR; with fire/rescue services on standby. After landing with no issues we taxied to the assigned gate and shut down the aircraft without issue.
Report 1_Synopsis: A320 First Officer reported an in-flight engine problem required a diversion and single-engine approach and landing.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Multiengine
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Issued New Clearance; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification
Report 1_Narrative: On approach to ZZZ gear was selected down but normal gear indications did not appear and there were no associated noises such as gear extending into slipstream; etc. PF (Pilot Flying) executed a missed approach and while being vectored we tried to lower the gear normally with the same indications and we got the L/G Gear Not Down locked ECAM. Accomplishing ECAM led us to the L/G Gravity Extension QRH and after accomplishing checklist the gear safely extended. We (advised ATC) and coordinated with Flight Attendants and Dispatch and ZZZ for subsequent runway closure and tow to the gate.
Report 1_Synopsis: A320 Captain reported a landing gear malfunction.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Multiengine
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; Flight Crew Executed Go Around / Missed Approach; General Maintenance Action
Report 1_Narrative: Aircraft X was uneventful leading up to the approach at ZZZ. We had been cleared for the approach to Runway XX and were established on the localizer and glideslope. The autopilot and autothrust had been disengaged earlier in the approach and the aircraft had been configured to Flaps 3 when Gear Down was requested. When the gear lever was selected down the three indicators on the landing gear panel indicated red UNLK (UNLOCKED); no noise from the landing gear doors opening was heard. Captain [Name] and I communicated and confirmed on the Landing Gear Systems page that the landing gear had not extended. We decided to level out at 6;000 feet MSL while we confirmed the situation and attempted to cycle the gear. We communicated to the tower we would be going around for a landing gear failure approximately 3mi prior to the runway. Tower provided vectors and a climb to 9;000 feet; we initiated a go around over the threshold per ATC instructions and cleaned up the aircraft per SOP. The autoflight was re-engaged after the go around. During this time after the failure of subsequent attempts to cycle the gear and with the lever still down; we eventually got the L/G GEAR NOT DOWNLOCKED ECAM. The ECAM was run according to SOP by Captain [Name] while I flew the aircraft and handled radio calls. We [received priority]; stated our intention to return to land on Runway XYR and requested CFR (Crash Fire Rescue Equipment). Gravity extension was successful and we were vectored to the approach. Approach and landing were normal with the exception of the gear doors remaining open. We landed with 8000 lbs. of fuel. We stopped on the runway and Operations was standing by to tow the aircraft back to the gate.
Report 1_Synopsis: First Officer reported a Go Around and precautionary  landing after landing gear lock problems.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP)
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Flight Crew Took Evasive Action; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; Flight Crew Inflight Shutdown; Flight Crew Diverted; General Flight Cancelled / Delayed; General Maintenance Action
Report 1_Narrative: Aircraft X departing from ZZZ bound for ZZZ1 scheduled to depart at XA:45. My FO (First Officer) and I both discussed the hydraulic maintenance write ups from the previous day and saw no obvious irregularities. All ground activities were normal; I.e. engine start and taxi. FO was the pilot flying; I was the pilot monitoring. Climb to our cruise altitude of FL380 was uneventful. Approximately 40 minutes into flight we got the B system engine low pressure light; we used the QRH procedures for this malfunction which resulted in the switch being turned off. We checked the system page and saw that our fluid quantity was rising and stabilized at 106% and pressure was at approximately 2700 psi. The #2 oil filter bypass light came on; we again used the QRH which had us reduce thrust on the #2 engine to see if the light would extinguish. After moving the throttle to idle the light was still illuminated which; as per the checklist; required us to shut down the engine. Immediately prior to shutting down the engine I contacted Purser with our plan to secure the engine; our ETA to ZZZ1; and state that no cabin prep would be necessary. He told us that a deadheading pilot was onboard so we asked that he send him forward to the cockpit. Upon completion of the Engine Failure or Shutdown Checklist we advised ATC; got a more direct turn to ZZZ1; and descended to FL240. Once established at FL240 we saw that our closest divert airport was ZZZ2; we requested and received ATC clearance direct to the field. Our decision to proceed to ZZZ2 vs. ZZZ1 was passed on to Purser. We tried initially to contact Dispatch by sending a 'Call me' message from the ACARS. It took quite a while to get a response containing a frequency and I think the actual first response we got from Dispatch was that they had noticed that we had descended and wondered if we were having an issue. We did confirm that we had shut down an engine and once a decision had been made to go to ZZZ2 we confirmed that with Dispatch through ACARS messaging. We had good communication with Center but were never able to speak to Dispatch; though as we got close to ZZZ2 we did hear ZZZ3 ARINC; though they could never hear us. At about the same time Center notified us that our company was trying to contact us on the frequency that we had previously been given; we told them that they could not hear us so they relayed our final intentions to the company. I can only assume that our altitude might have played a role in this poor communication with Dispatch; though we had no issues with ATC. In the approximately 45 minutes of cruise prior to descent into ZZZ2; we discussed steps taken; checklist to be completed (One Engine Inoperative Landing Checklist) and other considerations. As a result; I switched pilot flying and pilot monitoring duties. At approximately 60 miles from ZZZ2 we commenced our descent. With all checklists complete and planning for a flaps 15 approach to the ILS at ZZZ2; we were given an intercept heading and selected flaps 15 for landing. The flaps did not move; so we requested vectors across final while we troubleshot the flaps. At this time I assumed the duties of flying the aircraft and talking to ATC. [The other two pilots] took on the task of determining why the flaps did not extend. Shortly after; we checked our system page and discovered that we had zero B System hydraulic quantity; I do not recall the B system pressure. We decided to run the Loss of System B checklist which led us to electrically extend the flaps. After one more series of turns to intercept final; we fully configured and executed an uneventful approach and landing at ZZZ2. After being inspected by Fire and Rescue Crews we taxied to our gate.
Report 1_Synopsis: Captain reported loss of System B engine driven hydraulic pump and the number 2 engine filter bypass light illuminating resulted in an inflight shutdown of the number two engine and a diversion.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Multiengine
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Maintenance; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy
Events_Detector: Automation Aircraft Other Automation; Person Flight Crew
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Air Traffic Control Issued New Clearance; Flight Crew Returned To Departure Airport; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; General Flight Cancelled / Delayed; General Maintenance Action
Report 1_Narrative: Arriving at the aircraft and checking the logbook; I noticed that the last crew had written that the Takeoff Configuration light and horn activated on takeoff (speed of activation was not noted). I surmised that the crew rejected the takeoff and subsequently swapped out of the aircraft after returning to the gate and the aircraft was not flown afterwards. The corrective action was a check of the Takeoff Configuration Warning System with no faults noted. Since nothing was actually corrected; the Captain and I discussed the possibility of it activating again on our takeoff. We pushed late due to an unrelated finding of damage in the floor of the Forward Cargo Bin C. The bin was deferred and bags transferred to the aft bin. We were relatively full on this flight and our V1/VR speeds for Flaps 1 on Runway XXR were 125/135. The engine start and taxi out were uneventful with the throttle burst yielding no takeoff warning. On the takeoff roll at approximately 130 knot (5 knot after V1) the takeoff warning horn and light activated. We elected to continue the takeoff. The initial climb was normal and we discussed that we would be writing this up in ZZZ1. The Captain called for 'flaps up' at the appropriate speed and I moved the flap lever to UP. We had a few distractions from ATC due to hold-down altitude that was cancelled. Before I moved the landing gear handle to OFF; I checked the flap indicator and noticed that the flaps were still at 1 with the LE FLAP EXT green light illuminated. After confirming that the flap handle was up; I told the Captain the issue and that we need to keep our airspeed below 250 kts. and level off to handle the problem.After notifying ATC that we would need to level off; they gave us vectors for terrain while we ran the QRH for Trailing Edge Flap Disagree. Since the QRH doesn't really address the disagreement when attempting to RETRACT the flaps and only deals with setting the flaps for landing; we turned our attention to coordinating the air return. Dispatch was advised of the return as well as Station Ops in ZZZ. Our current gross weight was a little over 130;000 pounds so we extended the gear to add drag and burn off excess fuel for landing. The F/As (Flight Attendants) and passengers were notified of the return. Since this was a flight control issue; we [received priority handling] and notified ATC that we were requesting [Runway] XYL but would need time to reduce our landing weight to 128;000 pounds. We felt this was the safe option as time was not an issue. We then ran the QRH; ran the performance calculation for the Trailing Edge Flap Disagree QRH; and then the brake cooling module. The flaps extended normally with the Alternate Flap system to 15 degrees. The only slight issue was although I read the section directing the flap lever to be moved to the final flap position (15); we were sidetracked by discussing slowing during the extension and this was not done until after the QRH was completed. This allowed us to see our Flaps 15 maneuvering speed. After the delay vectors were complete and we were below the maximum landing weight; we made an uneventful landing on [Runway] XYL. Brake cooling allowed us to take right to the gate and the ARFF (Airport Rescue and Fire Fighting) trucks followed. No other issues occurred. We swapped into another aircraft and continued the pairing.
Report 1_Synopsis: Flight Crew reported a repeat failure of the Take Off Warning System and a failure of trailing edge flaps to retract caused an Air Tun Back and a precautionary emergency landing.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP)
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Inflight Event / Encounter Fuel Issue
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Flight Crew Diverted; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; General Maintenance Action; General Flight Cancelled / Delayed
Report 1_Narrative: Prior to departure Maintenance was called due to FOs (First Officer's) MAP failure on navigation display. Maintenance did a reset and signed off logbook as reset ok for service. FOs MAP was restored. Approximately 2 hours into flight and approximately 30 mins from ZZZZ1 enroute to ZZZZ; FOs MAP failed; followed by Captain's CWS (control wheel steering) fail; autothrottle failure; and SINGLE FMC operation message. Very shortly later; approximately 10 seconds; LNAV/ VNAV failed; both FMCs failed. Opposite autopilot selected; autopilot B. Captain's CWS was restored and one FMC was restored allowing for the engagement of LNAV/VNAV; and autothrottle was restored. FOs MAP still indicated a failure. Within approximately 60 seconds we had another dual FMC failure; followed by another LNAV/ VNAV failure; autothrottle failure; Captain's CWS failure. At this time with over two hours left to ZZZZ and navigating by raw data we decided it was the best course of action to divert to ZZZZ1 where the weather was favorable for landing with these navigational failures. We notified ZZZZ1 Center of our issues and intent to land in ZZZZ1. Around this time the Captain's FMC was restored automatically and we were once again able to navigate with LNAV/VNAV and the autothrottle and Captain's CWS was restored and autopilot was operational. As we neared ZZZZ1 we informed ATC of the need to hold to burn off fuel due to being overweight for landing which took approximately 10 minutes. The remainder of the flight was uneventful; we landed on Runway X and commenced the ILS approach in VFR conditions. The FOs MAP warning flag remained in view for the rest of the flight. My FO; Fas (Flight Attendants) did outstanding jobs. Great communication. ZZZZ1 ATC also very professional and helpful. In the 21 years I've been on the 737 both as an CA (Captain) and FO I've never experienced a dual FMC failure. I've experienced several single FMC failures; but not dual failures leading to several other navigation failures.
Report 1_Synopsis: Captain reported a diversion to a precautionary landing following the loss of both Flight Management Computers which caused the loss of Cockpit Display Units and most navigation systems.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Multiengine
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Inflight Event / Encounter Loss Of Aircraft Control
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Flight Crew Returned To Departure Airport; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification; Flight Crew Regained Aircraft Control; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; Flight Crew Landed As Precaution; Flight Crew Took Evasive Action; General Flight Cancelled / Delayed; General Maintenance Action
Report 1_Narrative: I was Pilot Flying. Just after liftoff; the nose trim ran high speed nose up on its own. I waited a quick moment and told the Captain that I was not doing that trim command; and then pushed forward on the yoke to stop the runaway. After retracting the flaps; I relaxed forward pressure and the trim continued nose up runaway at slow speed. I pressed the electric time nose down on the yoke; and the up trim stopped its uncommanded nose up runaway. Then we ran the Stabilizer Runaway Checklist and returned back to ZZZ uneventfully.
Report 1_Synopsis: Pilot reported a runaway stabilizer trim system and elected to air turn back and make a precautionary emergency landing.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Flight Instructor; Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Multiengine
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Maintenance; Inflight Event / Encounter Aircraft
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Aircraft Equipment Problem Dissipated; Flight Crew Inflight Shutdown; Flight Crew Diverted; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; General Flight Cancelled / Delayed; General Maintenance Action
Assessments_Contributing Factors / Situa: Aircraft; Equipment / Tooling; Incorrect / Not Installed / Unavailable Part
Report 1_Narrative: During preparation for our flight; all pre-flight items and activities were normal. There were no discrepancies were noted.  We departed ZZZ for ZZZ1. Once in cruise; the Captain and I noticed the oil quantity decreasing. We consulted the QRH for low oil quantity. As the quantity continued to decrease; the Captain called dispatch and maintenance for any guidance or assistance they could give.  The tech told the Captain to follow the QRH.  The Captain and I began discussing engine shutdown and diversion scenarios. The oil level eventually fell to zero. Over a period of time; the oil pressure also began to fall slowly and we now were consulting the low oil pressure and engine shutdown procedures in the QRH.  In the descent to ZZZ airport ; the oil pressure dropped to where the QRH directs engine shutdown. We followed the engine shutdown checklist and [advised the TRACON]. We were vectored for a Visual approach to runway XX. When we transferred to ZZZ1 tower; we were cleared to land. A few miles from landing; ZZZ1 tower advised us that ZZZ2 tower reported possible missing cowlings from our engine. The Captain informed me that he was going to stop on the runway to find out if there was aircraft damage before proceeding to the gate. The landing and rollout were normal and we stopped the aircraft on the runway. After an inspection of the aircraft; the fire commander gave us the all clear to proceed to our gate with rescue personnel following. At the gate and after the jet bridge was brought to the aircraft; we were met by two mechanics. We briefed them on the situation and they went outside to investigate. Once they opened the cowls; I went down to find out if they had any idea what happened. I could see that the inner cowl was covered with oil on the inside; but there was no evidence of oil on the outside of the nacelle and only a little had dripped on the ground. I was told by one of the mechanics that they found an 'oil plug' in the bottom of the inside cowl when they opened the engine cowls. I returned to the cockpit to brief the Captain with the information I acquired on the ramp.
Report 1_Synopsis: Flight Crew reported a loss of engine oil quantity and a loss of oil pressure caused an inflight shut down of the engine and an ATC guided landing.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Multiengine
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Less Severe; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Clearance; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy; Flight Deck / Cabin / Aircraft Event Smoke / Fire / Fumes / Odor
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; General Maintenance Action
Report 1_Narrative: About one hour from landing; we started to smell a faint burning scent from the packs. It was very faint; but noticeable. It smelled like glycol or plastic burning. It remained constant until we initiated a descent from FL390-FL370. The smell became more pronounced. For lack of another checklist or procedure; we ran the smoke fire and fumes QRH. The smell was only in the cockpit and not the cabin. Since we could not determine the source. We deemed it appropriate to take the safest course of action to expedite getting the aircraft on the ground with no undue delay. We [advised ATC] and asked for CFR (Crash Fire Rescue) to meet us to check for anything out of the ordinary upon landing. We initiated a high speed descent and approach; and performed a safe landing. CFR met the aircraft and checked it over and we taxied to the gate.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737-800 First Officer reported a flight deck fumes event during cruise.  The crew ran the appropriate QRH checklist and continued to destination.

Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy; Inflight Event / Encounter Fuel Issue
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Flight Crew Diverted; Flight Crew Inflight Shutdown; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; General Flight Cancelled / Delayed; General Maintenance Action
Report 1_Narrative: Shortly after takeoff; we noticed a fuel imbalance of about 1;200 pounds with the right tank showing a lower quantity. As we were monitoring the fuel gauges; Flight Attendant called to advise a passenger noticed fluid coming out of the right wing after takeoff. Captain was able to balance the fuel.After established in cruise for about 10 min; started to notice another fuel imbalance in progress. Captain ran FUEL LEAK QRH and noted time and fuel quantities. Got to a fuel imbalance of 650 pounds within 20 min.At this point Captain and I concurred that it looked like we had a fuel leak. Advised ATC of the situation and requested to divert to ZZZ1. Continued and finished QRH checklist. Performed an engine shutdown followed by a single engine landing.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737 flight crew reported a fuel leak required an in flight shut down of an engine and a diversion.
