Report 1_Narrative: In cruise we got a ECAM alert of hydraulic blue sys low press followed by blue hydraulic low quantity. Followed ECAM checklist and contacted Dispatch to discuss option. Determined it best to continue to ZZZ. We advised ATC and landed on Runway XX.It was an unforeseen event that was handled according to company passengers and policies.
Report 1_Synopsis: A319 flight crew reported loss of Blue System hydraulic pressure and quantity resulted in a precautionary landing.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Multiengine
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Issued New Clearance; Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Flight Crew Executed Go Around / Missed Approach; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification
Report 1_Narrative: I was Pilot Flying. On approach to Runway XXR at ZZZ; after calling for the landing gear down and flaps 15; we noticed that we had three green and three red landing gear indications. The overhead panel showed three green indications. We were able to complete the QRH and Landing Checklist and determined that the landing gear was down and locked. We continued the approach with the intention of landing. At approximately 500 feet AGL; we received the oral warning 'TOO LOW GEAR.'I was no longer sure that the landing gear was down and locked.  I called for the go-around and executed the go-around procedure.  We decided to leave the landing gear down and cleaned the flaps up to 5 degrees.  The Captain was working the radios and informed ATC of the go-around.  ATC gave us a heading and cleared us to 2;000 feet. They asked for the reason of the go-around. The Captain informed them that we were having landing gear indication problems. The Captain then decided to request priority handling.We completed the QRH and were able to get three green indications without red indications. The Captain informed ATC we had solved the problem and could continue for another approach and landing.  ATC assigned us Runway XXL.  We set up the FMC; re-briefed the approach; completed all of the appropriate checklists; flew the approach; and landed uneventfully on Runway XXL.  We taxied to the gate; shut down the engines and completed the Shut Down Checklist. While at the gate we had realized that due to workload; we had forgotten to inform the flight attendants of the priority handling situation.To prevent this from happening again; we need to slow down; and complete all briefings to the Flight Attendants and Passenger cabin prior to landing. Just because we were able to solve the landing gear problem and workload was heavy; does not alleviate the duty to inform the Cabin Crew.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737-700 First Officer reported a landing gear indication issue during approach resulting in a go-around.  The flight crew ran the QRH procedures; resolved the issues and landed safely on their second attempt.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Multiengine
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical
Events_Result: Flight Crew Inflight Shutdown; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition
Report 1_Narrative: While descending through approximately 20;000 feet on the arrival we encountered a compressor stall with self recovery on engine number 1 (heard loud popping; aircraft experienced slight yaw moment).  All engine parameters indicated normal. PM (Pilot Monitoring) briefed the Flight Attendants and made a PA to the passengers explaining what happened.  Approximately 3 minutes later we had an indication of N2 overspeed (~103%). PF (Pilot Flying) reduced thrust on the engine to bring it within normal limits which was immediately followed by a ENG 1 FUEL CNTRL FAULT. FO (First Officer) continued to fly the airplane while CA (Captain) was completing the ECAM procedure. The ECAM procedure directed the ENG 1 to be shut down. PF notified ATC and requested vectors to final approach for Runway XXL. PM completed the ECAM procedure and the QRH follow up for the ENG FAIL. PM briefed the Flight Attendants on a Precautionary Landing according to the Non Routine Landing Considerations. PM conducted a PA to the passengers to explain the situation and to expect ARFF (Aircraft Rescue & Fire Fighting) to check the airplane on the outside. We were cleared for a visual approach to Runway XXL which we backed up with the ILS. PF conducted a normal approach and landing and stopped the aircraft on the runway short of Taxiway D.  PM requested that the Fire Commander check the outside of the aircraft for any damage or leaks. After ARFF inspected the aircraft and reported no signs of damage or leaks we taxied to the gate.  After arriving at the gate; we called Dispatch to notify them of the precautionary landing.  Dispatch patched us through to Maintenance Control.  We discussed the ECAM / engine indications with Maintenance to aid in the log discrepancy write up.
Report 1_Synopsis: A319 flight crew reported engine compressor stall during descent.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Multiengine
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation - Altitude Overshoot; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Clearance
Events_Result: Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition
Report 1_Narrative: During cruise STAB OUT OF TRIM light illuminated intermittently.  Complied with STAB OUT OF TRIM QRH procedure.  Maintenance notified via ACARS. Descending with autopilot and autothrottle on; aircraft did not level off at the preselected 4;000 feet.  I disconnected the autopilot and autothrottle and began to return to 4;000 feet.  I tried the electric trim and found it to be inoperative.  I notified the Captain of the inoperative electric trim.  The Captain tried his electric trim and also found it to be inoperative. Captain conferred with me about disconnecting the STAB TRIM CUT OUT switches.  I agreed and the STAB TRIM CUT OUT switches were disconnected.  Captain opened the QRH and we complied with the STAB OUT OF TRIM QRH procedure.  The STAB OUT OF TRIM QRH procedure directed us to the STABILIZER TRIM INOPERATIVE procedure; which we complied with.  I tried to operate the manual trim with my left hand could not move the trim wheel through a full rotation.  I notified the Captain of this and he tried the manual trim.  Captain seem to require both hands to operate the manual trim.  Captain notified ATC and we requested delay vectors. We requested the longer Runway of XXR.  We performed a flaps 15 landing on XXR.  Descended below assigned altitude of 4;000 feet due to malfunctioning elevator trim.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737-900 flight crew reported Stab Trim failure resulted in an altitude overshoot and limited control ability.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Multiengine
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Aircraft Aircraft Damaged; Flight Crew Took Evasive Action; Flight Crew Returned To Gate; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; Flight Crew Rejected Takeoff; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification; General Flight Cancelled / Delayed; General Maintenance Action
Report 1_Narrative: Cleared to line up and wait Runway XX. When cleared for takeoff; pushed power to approximate 40% then selected TO/GA. As the thrust levers advanced; there was a very loud bang and yaw to the left. We had just started rolling. The thrust levers were brought to idle and we stopped on the runway. Initially; with the bang and yaw I thought we hit something or ran over something. As I was looking out the window; the First Officer stated we had a #1 Engine failure. Tower asked if we wanted equipment. We asked if they saw smoke or damage; and they replied 'No'; along with another aircraft on the taxiway. I made a PA for everyone to remain seated. I then called the F/A's (Flight Attendants) and asked them to look at the Captain side engine for smoke or flames. They reported it looked normal. We ran the Engine Failure Checklist; and discussed running the Rejected Takeoff Checklist. Since the event happened as the aircraft had just started to roll (probably less than 10 knots) we didn't run the Rejected Takeoff Checklist; knowing that brake energy and cooling wouldn't be an issue. After we taxied to the gate; I made calls to Dispatch; Maintenance; and the Chief Pilot on call; while the First Officer went to the ramp to inspect the aircraft. He discovered bent and broken turbine blades with metal pieces loose in the engine. He came back upstairs and called ZZZ Ground to do a runway check for engine debris. I made a PA to the passengers explaining that we had an engine failure at power up; and the aircraft would be taken out of service. They would receive more flight information in the terminal. After the passengers had deplaned; the crew got together and debriefed the event. I informed the F/As of what had happened and let them ask questions.
Report 1_Synopsis: Captain reported engine failure on take off roll causing a rejected take off and a return to the gate.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Multiengine
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy
Events_Result: Aircraft Aircraft Damaged; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; Flight Crew Returned To Gate; Flight Crew Regained Aircraft Control; General Flight Cancelled / Delayed; General Maintenance Action
Report 1_Narrative: After the addition of thrust for T/O (takeoff) and selection of TO/GA (takeoff go-around) and N1 attaining T/O power; the aircraft was already rolling and had achieved approximately 15 knots of forward motion.  At that point we heard a very loud bang followed by a hard left yawing motion. The PF (Pilot Flying) immediately retarded the throttles to idle; and applied smooth breaking; which brought us to a complete stop.  We were angled left by about 30-40 degrees in relation to the center line of Runway 4; just prior to taxiway. I immediately informed ATC that we had stopped on the runway; the PF informed the PAX (passengers) to stay seated.  At that point we began to assess the situation. Initially we thought it was a blown tire or nose wheel steering issue. In that moment of assessing I noticed the #1 Engine Fail Caution illuminate in the #1 EGT Gauge. I informed the PF of the indication. It was the only indication we saw. No fire; no red lines only the engine failure alert caution. We reviewed the Rejected Takeoff Procedure; completed the QRH for Engine Failure. We then assessed the rolling and breaking capability of the aircraft and we found it to be normal.  We got clearance to exit the runway and return to the gate. As we pulled in to the gate; we remembered that we had not run an After Landing Checklist and quickly completed that; followed by the Parking Checklist. Then; the jetbridge malfunctioned and we had to wait until Airport Ops came to fix it. Once the jetbridge was attached I exited the aircraft to inspect Engine #1. I found the N1 fan blades and the stators directly behind them to be in a normal appearance. When I looked into the tailpipe of the turbine section; I found metal debris from the engine and both the aft fan blades and stators in front of them to be damaged and missing pieces. I hustled back to the Flight Deck to inform Ground Control that they needed to do a FOD check of the runway as we had; had and engine failure and that they needed to check for small engine parts.
Report 1_Synopsis: First Officer reported engine failure on take off roll; resulting in engine damage and a return to the gate.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Commercial; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP)
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Maintenance; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy; Inflight Event / Encounter Loss Of Aircraft Control
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Separated Traffic; Flight Crew Landed As Precaution; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; Flight Crew Diverted; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; Flight Crew Regained Aircraft Control; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification; Flight Crew Returned To Departure Airport; General Flight Cancelled / Delayed
Report 1_Narrative: All preflight items complete INCLUDING Main Electric STAB TRIM CUTOUT switch with normal results. Student Captain was Pilot flying for this leg. Shortly after Takeoff the PF commented that his electric trim switch was not working and asked me to try mine; which also did not work. I asked him if the elevator was working and he replied that it was and felt normal. We asked ATC to level off at 12;000 ft to work on a flight control issue and was approved. We did not ask for priority handling at this time...we engaged the A Autopilot successfully but shortly after the 'STAB OUT OF TRIM' light came on. As we began to look up the appropriate Non-normal; the PF disengaged the autopilot and tried to manually trim the stabilizer. Although he was successful it looked like it was difficult to rotate so I asked to give it a shot to feel the force required to rotate. The force required to rotate was abnormally high but did provide results and we were flying a trimmed aircraft at 240 knots. By now I was considering that a Jammed Flight Control (the stabilizer in this case) was the source of our STAB OUT OF TRIM  problem. So the first checklist we addressed was the Jammed or Restricted Flight Controls Non-normal and also the Jammed or Restricted Flight Controls procedure (the script/expanded explanation). Around this time we requested priority handling with ATC because checklist called for landing at nearest suitable airport. We were hoping that we might get electric trim back when moving STAB TRIM switch on pedestal to OVERRIDE. Did not happen. Called Dispatch with Maintenance Control on the line hoping for some systems expertise. Ended call with where we started. We began to discuss possible value of running STAB OUT OF TRIM checklist. We did. But before doing so we noted the hazard of running multiple checklists and capped our STAB TRIM OVERRIDE switch to normal. The Jammed Flight Control non normal resulted in moving both STAB  TRIM switches to CUTOUT but also called for landing at nearest suitable with Flaps 15. About this time we got on radio again with Maintenance Control; Dispatch and also the Flight Operations. Our hope was that Flight Operations might be able to get a Hydraulics of Flight Controls Maintenance expert on with us. We discussed both checklists and Flight Operations talked about the potential effect of slower speeds. This call ended with general consensus we were on the best track and we discussed whether to land sooner or burn down to below Max landing weight. Because we felt the aircraft was stable and our condition was not likely to get worse we chose to burn fuel. I talked to PF and told him it would be prudent for me to do landing since that would be his first one from left seat in aircraft. We briefed our arrival plan which included our trim plan as we reduced airspeed and extended gear and flaps. As we descended and slowed we reminded ATC of need for priority handling equipment. Only significant thing to report was that by the time we had fully configured and slowed to final approach speed it was extremely difficult to trim manually. In fact; with one pilot exerting maximum effort; you could maybe get the manual strection about a quarter turn. All of this led us to believe that the Stabilizer was DEFINITELY jammed. Landed uneventfully; had equipment check us out then taxied to gate. Flight Attendants were given TEST brief and told there was no need to prepare for evacuation.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737 NG flight crew reported a jammed horizontal stabilizer trim system and elected to make an Air turn Back and precautionary landing.

Report 1_Narrative: Just prior to leveling off at FL340; Flight Attendant called and stated there was an electrical burning smell in the forward galley. There was not any smoke nor fire; just an odor. We notified ATC; turned back toward ZZZ; accomplished all checklist items; and landed uneventfully. After clearing the runway; we had the fire department check the airplane for signs of a fire. They saw nothing so we taxied back to the gate. At the gate; the fire department came on board to check the galley. They found nothing. No deviations from FARs.
Report 1_Synopsis: A320 flight crew reported an 'electrical burning smell' during initial climb resulting in a return to the departure airport.

Report 1_Narrative: Weather event departing from DFW on climb out on vectors out of around 12;000 AC (Aircraft) was hit by lightning on left side; left engine shut down; but spooled back up; then within seconds RT engine was struck by lightning AC lost radar. We [advised ATC and] requested vectors back to DFW. Weather was bad on climb out in all quadrants; departures should have not resumed so quickly. Wait until weather had moved further from the area before resuming departures.
Report 1_Synopsis: Air Carrier Flight Crew reported Lightning strike during climb.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP)
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy

Events_Result: Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; Flight Crew Diverted
Report 1_Narrative: While at cruise FL360; we received an ECAM advisory for low oil quantity on the Number 2 engine. After consulting with Dispatch and Maintenance Control about continuing the flight with this advisory a decision was made to divert to ZZZ. The decision to divert was made prior to ZZZZZ Intersection. In order to facilitate a direct routing to ZZZ; we requested priority handling with ATC. After this decision was made the oil pressure began to deteriorate; it reached the point where the ECAM low oil pressure procedure activated. We complied with the ECAM procedure and shut the engine down. Advised ATC the we were changing our status to a priority handling aircraft; and advised Dispatch of the engine shutdown; with their concurrence we continued to ZZZ and made an overweight landing. A gradual descent from cruise altitude was flown while we complied with ECAM; QRH and company procedures. This gradual descent and landing at ZZZ also facilitated a landing closer to maximum landing weight.
Report 1_Synopsis: A319 Captain reported receiving a low oil ECAM warning for the Number 2 engine during cruise.  The crew followed QRH procedures and decided to shut the engine down and divert to the nearest suitable airport.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Multiengine
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation - Altitude Excursion From Assigned Altitude; Deviation - Speed All Types; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Clearance; Inflight Event / Encounter Weather / Turbulence

Report 1_Narrative: After descending from cruise flight at 360; we leveled off at FL300. We entered the clouds on descent and activated the engine anti ice system. Once level for a few minutes at 300 I noticed a rapid drop of airspeed on my side. I pushed the throttles up and informed the Captain. At that point we realized we had unreliable airspeed on the First Officer side. The Captain assumed control of the aircraft. We had encountered a small amount of rime icing and decided to climb back up. At this point we also realized the Captains altimeter was off. We [advised] through ATC; ran the QRC and QRH checklists. We diverted to ZZZ. We advised Dispatch and the flight attendants of our situation. Passing 15;000 feet our instruments began to return to normal and were equal upon landing.  We also accomplished they overweight landing checklist. We landed at ZZZ without incident. I believe the icing conditions could have contributed to the event. Check the pitot static system. Or computers. We had no indication of any heat malfunction.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737-800 flight crew reported icing conditions resulted in unreliable airspeed indications; followed by a descent and diversion to a precautionary landing.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Instrument
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Aircraft Aircraft Damaged; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification; Flight Crew Returned To Departure Airport; General Flight Cancelled / Delayed; General Maintenance Action
Report 1_Narrative: While climbing through 9;000 ft. MSL out of ZZZ; we experienced two VERY loud bangs from the #2 engine. We immediately suspected a compressor stall. Scanning the engines; I noticed the #2 engine decreasing in RPM. I immediately pulled the #2 engine to idle and it stabilized there. We coordinated a level-off at 9000 ft. with ZZZ Departure and flew an extended downwind. We ran all appropriate checklists and determined that the engine appeared to be performing normally. Following the checklist; we pushed the power up on the effected engine to approximately 80% with no adverse indications; there was no need to push it up any further. No [priority handling was requested] and we elected to return to ZZZ and fly a flaps 15 approach and landing to Runway 28R. Flight Attendants and Passengers were advised of the situation. After all checklist items were complete; we accomplished an uneventful approach and landing. Weight or brake energy was not a factor.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737 flight crew reported compressor stalls during climb and elected to return to the departure airport.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP)
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; Flight Crew Landed As Precaution; Flight Crew Diverted; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; General Flight Cancelled / Delayed; General Maintenance Action
Report 1_Narrative: Flight was scheduled to depart ZZZ. We arrived in the flight deck and performed all the normal procedures we have for a normal push back. Captain did the preflight walk around and I loaded the FMC. We agreed the OFP (Operational Flight Plan) looked good and the rest of the flight plan looked sufficient for a potentially bumpy ride to ZZZ1. Captain advised to Flight Attendants to stay seated out of ZZZ until we knew the ride would allow for their safe duties. I was the flying pilot and after Captain did his first flight of the day and PM (Pilot Monitoring) duty brief; I briefed the SID. We planned for a normal pushback with 2 engine start for a quick taxi for departure. We performed the BEFORE TAKEOFF CHECKLIST on taxi out down the ramp for takeoff on runway XX.While we were taxiing down to runway XX; I noticed there was a split between the L and R duct pressure. I made note of it to Captain and we briefly discussed these splits we have seen before in this aircraft and recall it being a known normal occurrence. I cycled the L PACK (Left) switch to OFF and back to AUTO as well as the ISOLATION VALVE switch to OPEN and AUTO and saw the duct pressure needles sync together. We decided it would be a safe action to depart and noted we would keep an eye on the duct pressure and pressurization.We departed runway XX and CLIMBED VIA THE SID. I hand flew the departure to the mid 20s and then turned the autopilot on. I noted Captain mentioned 2 different times that the aircraft was pressurizing normally though the duct pressure still was split. The ride was mostly good and the flight attendants were up but the seat belt was still on. As we approached our level off altitude of FL340 the CABIN ALTITUDE horn and the MASTER WARNING lights illuminated. We verified the CABIN ALTITUDE was high on the pressurization panel and performed the Immediate Action items for CABIN ALTITUDE WARNING OR RAPID DEPRESSURIZATION/EMERGENCY DESCENT. The CABIN ALTITUDE was not controllable; and we continued with the descent. There was a definite issue with immediate communication over the inter-phone with the masks on and all the noise. Getting the mask on and the audio panel correct to be able to speak and hear over the speaker poses a threat in this airplane if not practiced. We were able to communicate with each other and ATC but it was challenging with all the noise and distractions.Captain identified as a priority flight with ZZZ Center and we began the initial descent over the mountains. I initially turned off the AUTOPILOT to pitch over and begin the procedure. Once we were established in a descent; I turned the AUTOPILOT back on and descended to FL190 with the high terrain in mind. We saw an aircraft below us on the TCAS and had to shallow the descent initially before we were cleared lower. Captain proceeded with completing the checklist and communicating with the Flight attendants; passengers; and dispatch. Descending through approximately 16;000 feet I noticed the CABIN ALTITUDE was in a normal range of around 7;000 feet and we took off the oxygen masks. We leveled off at 11000 in the vicinity of ZZZ2. Initially we were planning on diverting to ZZZ2 because we were so close; but Captain's experience and familiarity with ZZZ3. This led to the decision to divert and there was difficulty communicating with dispatch possibly due to our low altitude so we opted to landing in ZZZ3. The flight attendants and passengers were all briefed for the diversion to ZZZ3. I left the AUTOPILOT on and we flew the RNAV (GPS) Runway XY 29 approach and landing. All checklists were completed before ZZZZZ intersection and the landing was normal. CFR ( Aircraft Rescue & Firefighting) was there upon arrival.We were parked at the hard stand in ZZZ3 and the ramp personnel brought over the ramp to allow the passengers to vacate the aircraft. Operations were there to help while we figured out the plan of action for the passengers. Captain discussed the situation with the ChiefPilot; Dispatch; and Maintenance and I aided the flight attendants with passengers. I walked to the OUTFLOW VALVE and noted a mesh substance blocking the OUTFLOW VALVE from fully closing. Captain manually opened and closed the valve and I videoed the movement.
Report 1_Synopsis: First Officer reported an emergency descent and diversion followed by a precautionary landing caused by Foreign Object Debris blocking the outflow valve from operation.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Instrument
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation - Speed All Types; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy
Events_Detector: Automation Aircraft Other Automation; Person Flight Crew
Events_Result: Flight Crew Diverted; Flight Crew FLC complied w / Automation / Advisory; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; Flight Crew Inflight Shutdown
Report 1_Narrative: Flight began from ZZZ as second leg of duty day.  Start; taxi and takeoff were uneventful.  Shortly after reaching cruise altitude of FL280; we noticed a low oil qty (0%) and dropping oil pressure (approximately psi). I called for QRH and Captain began running Low Oil Pressure Checklist.  While accomplishing the checklist; the oil pressure dropped below 15 psi and entered the Warning (Red) regime.  This drove us to shutdown the #1 engine.  Captain advised ATC and a gradual descent to FL 250 was initially begun.  After the shutdown was completed; we elected to begin diverting to ZZZ1 as it was only 50 miles away.  ATC; Flight Attendants and dispatch were all provided with necessary information to assist us as we requested Rwy XXL; but due to heavy traffic and closure of XXC; ATC requested we use XXR.  Landing data was run by both crew and dispatch and stopping distance was sufficient on the shorter runway.  While descending; I was momentarily distracted by the runway change and while simultaneously slowing to 200 kts Inattention caused us to slow to approximately 189 kts and we received an 'Airspeed Low' warning.  I accelerated back to 210 kts and requested Flaps 5.  We executed a normal approach and landing with 5 extra kts of speed due to a '10 kts of gain' on final report.  Once we landed; we exited the runway and requested Fire Chief to check us out.  After receiving the all clear; we taxied uneventfully to the gate and accomplished all checklists.  All events were debriefed in accordance with company debrief card.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737 flight crew reports inflight shutdown and airspeed low warning in descent.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Instrument
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Clearance; Inflight Event / Encounter Weather / Turbulence
Events_Result: Flight Crew Diverted; Flight Crew Inflight Shutdown; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition
Report 1_Narrative: FL340 approximately 160 nm east northeast of ZZZ the right engine OIL FILTER BYPASS caution annunciation flashed for 3-5 seconds then remained illuminated.  We advised ATC with clearance to descend as requested to FL200 (FL223 max single engine altitude capability).  Drift down profile initiated while concurrently performing required checklists; balancing fuel as needed as checklist directed engine shutdown.  Declared ZZZ as the nearest suitable divert at point in time. Notified dispatch of intent for ZZZ; as well as coordinating communications with the Purser and making a PA to the passengers.  Obtained ZZZ ATIS which stated winds variable at 6 kts landing Runway XX. Requested Runway XY for additional runway length.  Transitioned from drift down profile to a descent profile when a 3:1 profile attained. As we approached within 15 nm of the field; we were informed that winds were gusting in excess of 20 kts from the south.  We coordinated a runway change to XXL and at approximately 10-12 nm north of the field executed a left 360 degree turn descending to the sector MVA as to scrub altitude due to the much shortened landing distance to Runway XXL.Approach and landing was uneventful as was the taxi evolution to the gate for parking.  Fire crash and rescue followed and informed that there was no threat heat signature emanating from the landing gear/brake assemblies. Normal passenger deplaning ensued.ATC throughout the evolution was perfect in every respect in aiding the successful uneventful outcome.  A discrete frequency was assigned and that was immeasurably valuable.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737 flight crew reported an engine inflight shutdown in cruise due to an oil filter bypass issue.

Report 1_Narrative: FA (Flight Attendant) called as we were climbing to FL280 reporting dirty sock odor from Row 26 aft to galley. No odor in rest of cabin. No odor detected in flight deck. Asked FA to check lav; overhead bins; galley carts and storage areas. Nothing was found. Began getting data for landing in ZZZ1. Began referencing QRH for smoke procedure and overweight landing procedure. FO (First Officer) assumed Pilot Flying duties and ATC. FA (flight attendant) then informed us that occupants were becoming ill. We immediately notified ATC and requested diversion to ZZZ1. Informed ATC we had injuries. Sent ACARS to Dispatch advising of diversion. During descent completed QRH Overweight Landing procedure and began Smoke/Avionics Smoke/Fumes QRH 17-1 procedure. Stopped Smoke procedure while maneuvering for approach and assumed Pilot Flying duties. Uneventful overweight landing. Stopped aircraft on runway and called FA's to assess. Was notified that the odor had stopped. Requested taxi to gate. Taxied per ATC instructions to ramp. Ramp unaware of our condition and asked us to hold on the ramp. Attempted contact with Operations. No answer. Ramp was able to obtain gate information from company and cleared us to gate. Fire truck followed us to gate and fireman came onboard and said all was clear outside of aircraft. Requested paramedics. Waited for over 15 minutes to arrive. FA 3 and several passengers were ill and required treatment. Informed that odor had completely subsided. Passengers remained onboard to allow access for paramedics as ill occupants were blocking front galley area and jetbridge. Flight Attendants were very assertive in communicating the specifics of the odors and location including the condition of our passengers throughout the event. This played a significant role in understanding the condition in the cabin and making proper decisions. Odor events can be difficult to prevent. Preparing for these seemingly inevitable challenges can make them easier to manage.
Report 1_Synopsis: A321 flight crew reported a dirty sock" odor was detected in the cabin during cruise resulting in a diversion."

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP)
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy; Flight Deck / Cabin / Aircraft Event Other / Unknown

Report 1_Narrative: Proceeding directly to ZZZZZ intersection on the ZZZZZ 2 RNAV arrival. Was cleared to descend via ZZZZZ 2 RNAV arrival on [Runway] XXR. Prior to ZZZZZ; at approximately FL220 during descent; noticed that the cabin altitude was at 8;300 feet and increasing. I called attention to the First Officer that we might be losing cabin pressurization. The Pressurization screen on ECAM was displayed and noticed that both the inlet and extract valve were fully closed but the safety valve had opened.Since we had already been cleared to descend via ZZZZZ arrival and had an altitude of 12;000 set in the MCP I decided to expedite the descent to see if I could control the rate of ascent in the cabin. At approximately FL180 it appeared that we could not control the rate of ascent in the cabin and that at its present rate the cabin would exceed 10;000 feet shortly. I then [advised] with ATC and requested 10;000 feet which was granted. I advised the Lead Flight Attendant that we were experiencing cabin pressurization problems but to expect a normal landing. As we leveled at 10;000 feet I monitored the cabin and noticed that it had climbed to 12;000 feet but stabilized. It took several minutes before the cabin normalized at our cruise altitude of 10;000 feet. I asked the First Officer  to see if he could find an applicable checklist to run. During this time I maintained control of the aircraft and communicated with ATC. The First Officer advised that he was able to manually control the outflow valve and that the checklist recommended shallow descents thereafter. I continued to ask for delayed vectors from ATC just north of ZZZ as the First Officer and I reviewed the state of the aircraft and decided it was safe to proceed with the landing. I asked ATC for shallow descents on the arrival to [Runway] XXR into ZZZ. The landing and taxi in were uneventful.
Report 1_Synopsis: Air carrier Captain reported malfunctioning pressurization system on descent.

Report 1_Narrative: Aircraft was dispatched with an inoperative Pack #2 due to a regulator fault and [the flight] was in full compliance with the MEL at departure. Flight was completely full in the cabin. Due to Pack #2 being inoperative it was difficult to cool the main cabin temp using only Pack #1. Using only Pack #1 at FL370 we were able to maintain 72 degrees in the cabin using max cold and high flow. Approximately 200 nm west of ZZZ at FL370 we received an ECAM AIR PACK 1+2 FAULT. ATC was notified and [priority handling was requested]. Upon checking the pressurization and bleed air page; it appeared that Pack #1 was overheating showing an output temperature in amber yet we never received a Pack 1 OVHT ECAM. The cabin altitude was still under control. A descent to 10;000 ft. was initiated without exceeding the cabin altitude before we complied with the ECAM to turn off Pack #1 leaving us unpressurized. Contact was made with Dispatch and Maintenance Control to discuss the situation resulting in a diversion to ZZZ.
Report 1_Synopsis: Air Carrier Pilot Crew reported departing with one air cycle machine inoperative and during cruise flight the other air cycle machine indicated a fault condition necessitating a diversion.

Report 1_Narrative: Aircraft had been written up by the previous crew as having a potable water leak of unknown origin. Maintenance Techs did their inspection and could find no leaks or indication of water damage. They filled the water tank and signed the aircraft off for flight. Within 10 minutes of departure flight attendants report water tank was down to 70% and lavatory sinks had no water coming out. Within 25 minutes of departure tank was empty. We called Dispatch and Maintenance. Decision was made to return to ZZZ. Overweight landing was made because we had no idea where the water was leaking to and we did not want to expose ourselves to compounding failures. Advised ATC due to overweight landing. Landing was uneventful. ARFF followed us to the gate as we monitored brake temperatures.We suggest Maintenance review their task card for potable water leak of unknown origin and possibly make revisions.
Report 1_Synopsis: A321 Check Airman reported an Air Turn Back after maintenance failed to diagnose and correct a potable water system leak that reoccurred next flight.

Events_Anomaly: ATC Issue All Types; Conflict Airborne Conflict; Deviation - Track / Heading All Types; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Clearance; Inflight Event / Encounter Weather / Turbulence

Report 1_Narrative: This was in a B737-8 MAX which is not selectable on the menu.  Inbound to ZZZ; deviating west of the arrival due to a severe TS over ZZZZZ and also another TS touching ZZZZZ1 along with multiple significant CB radar returns just west of our direct line to ZZZZZ1.  We checked in with ZZZ Center and descended to or level at FL340. We were made aware that our deviation west of the arrival was causing the Controller difficulty in de-conflicting our descent due to departing traffic which was below us and to my understanding west of us.  Very busy controller with no time to discuss options.  I was approaching the west edge (absolutely as close as possible) of the last significant CB when the Controller told us in an excited tone to turn right 15 degrees and descent to FL280 (or maybe 240; I don't recall now).  The CB was about 4 mile ahead and 2 miles across in both directions and 15 degrees right would put us straight through the middle of it.  I started an immediate right and tried to ask my First Officer to tell the Controller we had to have farther right; but he saw me turning and read back the 15 degree instruction.  The Controller was immediately on to two or three other calls.  I asked my First Officer to tell the Controller the heading that we needed to fly and about then the Controller noticed that we had turned a bit extra and shouted at us because apparently another aircraft was departing in the corridor between the last CB and the big TS.  I immediately corrected back and flew through the middle of the CB I was trying to avoid which was where the Controller wanted us in the first place.  I also paused my descent very briefly to verify with the Controller that we were going to be safe still and we agreed on a heading of north as we passed directly through the cell.  Fortunately; despite passing though the small cell with a solid yellow return; there was no significant turbulence and no injuries.  I don't believe we caused loss of separation and my intention was to coordinate and return to the desired heading as soon as possible. The frequency was too busy; departures probably should have been pushed farther west; I was trying to comply with the Controller's guidance as best I could while not creating a dangerous turbulence situation for my flight attendants and passengers.  The B737-8 MAX radar might be overly sensitive.  Had the Controller asked 30 seconds sooner we would have had time to coordinate; or a minute later we could have taken any heading.  In retrospect; we should have said we were unable to turn for another 6 miles; but given the urgency in the Controller's voice; I thought I was doing the right thing.Whenever an airplane is cleared to deviate for weather and is operating around thunderstorms and significant CBs; it seems like the Controller should always ask if you can accept a turn; not just assign a heading into the direction of the things we are avoiding.  Also; if there is any way to make these frequencies less congested; that would help also.  And finally; the other company's aircraft was apparently flying outbound and closer to our assigned arrival than we were comfortable with flying inbound.  Maybe ZZZ Center should develop and publish alternate Departure and Arrivals that could be assigned for weather avoidance as widespread thunderstorms are so common in this area.
Report 1_Synopsis: Air carrier First Officer reported a weather deviation was required but the very busy ATC controller was unable to accommodate the request. A heading deviation and airborne conflict may have resulted.

Report 1_Narrative: [The] flight departed ZZZ; [runway] XXL and at 400 ft. we were given a heading of 360. As soon as the turn was initiated a loud bang was heard from below and behind the cockpit. The noise then went away. A few moments later FA (Flight Attendant) 1 called up and reported a loud banging noise from 2R. There were no ECAM or any other indications in the cockpit - all displays were normal - nor was the noise audible from the cockpit. After getting the airplane stabilized and the after-takeoff checks completed; I sent the FO (First Officer) back to investigate. It was confirmed that a loud banging was obvious in the cabin. A return to the field was planned; ATC notified; [priority handling was requested]; FA's briefed for a precautionary landing; Dispatch notified and CFR (Crash Fire Rescue) requested. Runway XY was requested as this was an overweight landing; and the QRH procedure was followed. A smooth landing followed; the aircraft was brought to a stop after clearing Runway XY and the airplane inspected by CFR crew. The comment was that; 'A door was missing.' No other damage noted; and the flight taxied to a gate uneventfully. A walk-around revealed the 2R slide door departed the aircraft; followed by the slide. The noise was from the inflation supply line which was banging against the fuselage and wing root. A write-up for the missing door and raft was entered into the log along with the overweight landing notes. [The cause can be found through] perhaps confirmation of all maintenance items accomplished during the inspection at ZZZ immediately previous to this event. [I suggest to find the] determination of why the slide/raft door failed and [to find] appropriate remedies [to be] taken to preclude future issues.
Report 1_Synopsis: A321 flight crew reported a loud bang followed by repetitive banging aft of the cockpit door and elected to perform an air turnback where it was discovered that a slide and slide door had departed the aircraft.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Multiengine
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Maintenance; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural MEL / CDL
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification; Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; Flight Crew Returned To Departure Airport; General Maintenance Action
Report 1_Narrative: After takeoff; during gear retraction; we heard and felt 2-3 loud bangs and thuds with associated yaw and shutter of the aircraft. Initially; we considered a landing gear tire might have blown or it was retraction problem due to gear in transit timed with [another] problem. Once gear was fully retracted; a series of bangs and shutters occurred again and during our global assessment (Nothing displayed on ECAM); we noted a spike in temperature on engine 1 EGT as corresponding to the problem. [We suspected] compressor stalls. Reducing the power on engine 1 to idle eliminated the problem and the engine ran normally. We immediately [requested priority handling] with ATC requesting the ARFF equipment; as well as a box pattern back to XXR (longest runway); leveled at 4000 feet MSL; maintained configuration at 180 knots. We ran all appropriate checklists including: Engine 1 Stall in flight with Engine Parameters Normal at Idle; Non-Routine Landing; and Overweight Landing. We made an initial and landing imminent announcement to the flight attendants and passengers. During the initial series of compressor stalls and after the engine was stabilized at idle neither the flight attendants nor any passengers reported any other engine problems such as fire; smoke; vibrations; etc. Once everything was complete we flew the ILS XXC approach to a normal touchdown and landed to a full stop on the runway so that ARFF could look over the aircraft before we taxied uneventfully to the gate. Weight at touchdown was 3;000 to 4;000 pounds over the max with a 200 FPM touchdown. After shutdown; we made 2 logbook entries (Compressor stall after TO and Overweight Landing). We debriefed the Chief Pilot; Maintenance; ARFF Chief; Gate Agent; and Passengers. We saved all paper work; photos; and contact information.An Airbus Pilot jump-seater was very helpful with event CRM. Possible failure factors included heavy weight; TOGA takeoff; and a warm day stressing the engine. In addition; APU had been on MEL for 8 days adding to engine fatigue and stress with ground air and cross-bleed starts; and it was the aircraft's first flight of the day (even with ample warm-up time). Following policies; procedures; flows; and checklists all while maintaining positive aircraft control in an un-rushed manner using all available resources and thorough CRM led to a safe resolution to the engine failure on takeoff. [I recommend] better and more prompt APU maintenance; and the use of non-TOGA flex takeoffs on longer runways in hot and heavy takeoffs situations.
Report 1_Synopsis: A321 flight crew reported a possible compressor stall on the number 1 engine shortly after takeoff which resulted in a return to the departure airport.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Attendant Current

Events_Result: Flight Crew Overcame Equipment Problem; General Evacuated; General Flight Cancelled / Delayed; General Maintenance Action; General Physical Injury / Incapacitation
Report 1_Narrative: On Aircraft X ZZZ1 - ZZZ during final descent I noticed an oily/burning fumes that was present in the entire AFT of the aircraft but intense towards the middle AFT of the aircraft and was coming from the air vents. We communicated with each other as a crew and confirmed that all inflight [Cabin Attendants] (F1;F2;F3;F4) detected the fumes. The intensity was a Level 2: Moderate. During this phase my symptoms were the following: burning eyes; nose and throat. Flight deck was notified. After deplaning the fumes and my symptoms dissipated. Maintenance came on board and decided we would continue our next flight with same aircraft. On Aircraft X ZZZ to ZZZ1 during boarding when engines were turned on I immediately detected the oily burning fumes that were now at a Level 3: Strong since customers began to complain as well. The location started initially in the AFT of the aircraft but during deplaning was detectable throughout entire aircraft. The source was the same which was the air vents. The phase was during boarding on the ground. Flight deck was notified and they determined we had to deplane all customers. Myself and F4 were experiencing more severe symptoms. I experienced symptoms of burning eyes; nose and throat once again. I also began to feel tightness in my chest; difficulty breathing; thickness in the air; slight disoriented; and minor speech problems. Due to my symptoms I felt as though I was unable to perform my inflight duties safely. [Medical staff] was contacted when off the aircraft. Myself and the F4 were sent to the hospital.
Report 1_Synopsis: A320 Flight Attendant crew reported a fume event during boarding resulting in flight delay/cancellation.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Instrument; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP)

Report 1_Narrative: During the takeoff roll; the FA's (Flight Attendant's) dinged us twice. We continued the takeoff. Upon rotation they dinged us four times; twice before clean-up altitude. After reaching clean-up altitude I called the cabin and the FA's reported passengers seeing flames and sparks coming from the right engine; as well as hearing popping noises. The FA's reported the entire cabin lit up brightly; but that there was no smoke in the cabin. We informed ATC that we had a #2 engine fire; were returning for landing; and requested fire truck assistance. We had no cockpit indications of a fire or malfunction. Both engines were producing symmetric power and operating normally; according to our gauges. Upon landing and shutting down the engines on Taxiway XX; Fire Rescue took temperature readings and reported them in the normal range. We were towed to the gate.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737-700 flight crew reported an engine fire that was noticed by the passengers during takeoff and performed an air turnback.

Report 1_Narrative: Enroute from ZZZ to ZZZ1. Aircraft had MEL for #2 engine generator. Dispatched with APU powering #2 transfer bus. At 35;000 ft. over ZZZ2; APU failed and did automatic shutdown. We diverted to ZZZ2 due to only one AC power source remaining. Uneventful approach and landing. Multiple; unforeseen failures caused the event.
Report 1_Synopsis: B737-700 flight crew reported an APU failure inflight combined with an MEL'd engine generator resulted in single-generator operations; which led to a diversion to the nearest suitable airport.

Person 1_Qualification: Flight Crew Multiengine; Flight Crew Air Transport Pilot (ATP); Flight Crew Instrument
Events_Anomaly: Aircraft Equipment Problem Critical; Deviation / Discrepancy - Procedural Published Material / Policy
Events_Result: Air Traffic Control Provided Assistance; Flight Crew Landed in Emergency Condition; Flight Crew Requested ATC Assistance / Clarification; Flight Crew Returned To Departure Airport; Flight Crew Returned To Gate; General Flight Cancelled / Delayed; General Maintenance Action
Report 1_Narrative: CONF 1 TOGA takeoff and no APU. Normal start go #1 at the gate per non-normal start; the same for the #2 start after the push back. After-start check complete; load closeout comes. We were under PTOW (Planned Takeoff Weight) and good winds and temperatures. Normal taxi and checklist to [runway] XXC. Cleared for takeoff; CA sets TOGA. Normal acceleration Vr. Shortly after Vr; heard a loud bang - CA (Captain) says; 'I think we blew a tire.' I said; 'I agree.' CA kept flying; we left the gear down. Speed was bleeding off; and then I said 'engine failure.' [Requested priority handling] with intentions to return to ZZZ. Leveled off at engine acceleration height [and] started to accelerate; thinking the gear was up. We decided to leave the flaps at 1 to return to the field and not knowing if there was any damage. [We] completed the ECAM procedure; follow-ups. CA talked to the FA's (Flight Attendant) to prepare for a precautionary landing and made a PA to the passengers; per the OD pages. ATC asked us to climb to 4;000 ft. Then; we realized the gear was still down. [We] raised the gear [and] completed the after-takeoff checklist. Did the landing approach; overweight landing; and checklist. Briefed the approach to [runway] XXC and descent checklist. Configured on schedule; landing checklist; and landed uneventfully. After stopping; the CA made a PA; talked to ARFF (Aircraft Rescue and Fire Fighting); then taxed to the gate.[The cause was a] startle effect and the initial confusion of a tire failure or an engine failure. That played a significant role in the distraction of the landing gear. [I suggest to] do a max weight V1 in the SIMs.
Report 1_Synopsis: A321 flight crew reported performing an air turnback after experiencing an engine failure on takeoff.
